msContents.summary: A collection of writings chiefly by Honorius Augustodunensis, of which nos. 2–22 are also found, in the same order, in Munich clm. 22225, copied between 1154–9 for Gerhard, abbot of Windberg. No. 22 is shorter in the Munich MS., and no. 21b consists of a heading only.

msItem.incipit: Cum proxime in nostro conventu resideres

msItem.note: (marginal note: Responsio Solitarii)
msItem.incipit: Peritissimi pictores Ambrosius et Augustinus Hieronymus et Gregorius
Cum vis populum alloqui in primis ori et pectori tuo.
msItem.note: Partly pr. PL 172 col. 813–1104 from an imperfect MS: the missing pieces (found on fol. 153v–162v in our MS.) pr. J. Kelle, Untersuchungen über das Spec. Eccles. des Honorius, Sitzungsber. Akad. Wiss. Wien, Phil.-Hist. Kl. 145 (1902), 2–19.
At the end of the Speculum (fol. 166–167v) is an apparently unpublished piece:
msItem.incipit: Hinch Arbitrium, inde Artificium.

msItem.note: An extra piece on an inserted leaf (fol. 161r)
msItem.incipit: Ecclesia, id est domus orationis, umbra et figura
msItem.note: Pr. Kelle, op. cit., p. 18 n. from MS. St. Florian xi. 244, 12th cent.

Insertions on other extra leaves (fol. 4, 158) are found in the main printed text. The arrangement of the main work in our MS. differs from PL, but appears to be the same as in the St. Florian MS. On variants in MSS. of the Speculum see Kelle, op. cit., pp. 28–44.
On fol. 18 there is a long marginal addition to the second sermon:
msItem.incipit: In candela tria considerantur lumen, cera, lichinus. Lumen lucet
msItem.explicit: cum ipsa regnetis in secula. Amen.

msItem.note: In the margins of the Speculum has been added a series of Latin verses, most of which are also found in the 12th-cent. St. Florian MS. already cited (Fl.); see Walther in Centralblatt für Bibliothekswesen 49 (1932), 330. The numbers in Walther’s Initia are not given where he only refers to Fl.

msItem.incipit: ✠In nuce tres species sunt Christi signa gerentes.
msItem.note: 2 lines.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Le Mans
msItem.incipit: Dat magus aurum thus myrram rex suscipit aurum.
msItem.note: 4 lines. PL 171 col. 1275. WIC 4063.

msItem.incipit: Lectus ager mola signant consociatos
msItem.note: 3 lines. Fl., fol. 21.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Le Mans
msItem.incipit: Vinea culta fuit, cultores premia querunt
msItem.note: 6 lines. WIC 20357: edition closest to this version in Hervieux, Les Fabulistes Latins iv, 1896, p. 353. Fl., fol. 24.

msItem.incipit: Cecus vociferat ut lucis munera querat
msItem.note: 4 lines. Fl., fol. 36v.

msItem.incipit: Est genus humanum cecum stultum quia vanum
msItem.note: 6 lines. Fl., fol. 36v.

msItem.incipit: Ante Deum sordet quem fęda scientia mordet.
msItem.note: Probably also in Fl., as Walther says the preceding poem has 7 lines.

msItem.incipit: Hęc sunt sex opera quę prestant gaudia vera
msItem.note: 4 lines. Fl., fol. 41v.

msItem.title: Another version of the corporal works of mercy
msItem.incipit: Esurit ille, ciba, sitit alter, pocula liba
msItem.note: 3 lines. Again probably in Fl., since Walther says the preceding poem has 7 lines.

msItem.incipit: Scis triplicem curam baculi signare figuram
msItem.note: 6 lines. Fl., fol. 53.

msItem.incipit: Angelus est missus est passus et in cruce Christus.
msItem.note: 4 lines. FL, fol. 55 and MS. Vienna 625, fol. 24. The edition quoted by WIC 991, contains a variant version.

msItem.incipit: Intus obit qui mente foris qui peccat in actu.
msItem.note: 2 lines. FL, fol. 63v. WIC 9516.

msItem.incipit: Sicut is qui invitatus renuit, quesitus refugit, sacris est altaribus admovendus
msItem.note: 2 lines.

msItem.incipit: Cuncta licent ubi nulla nocent, ubi crimen inultum
msItem.note: 2 lines.

msItem.incipit: Villa, boves, uxor, substantia, cura, voluptas
msItem.note: 2 lines. A variant of the verses of Hildebert. WIC 20336.

msItem.incipit: Hic ruit elatus, dum reprobat est reprobatus Phariseus.
msItem.note: 2 lines. Fl., fol. 154v

msItem.incipit: Gratia debetur mihi vobis officiante
msItem.note: 2 lines. Fl., fol. 155.

msItem.incipit: Tres partes factę de Christi corpore signant
msItem.note: 4 lines. WIC 19401. Apparently a version of Hildebert, cf. WIC 18193.

msItem.incipit: Cordis scrutator est confessoris amator
msItem.note: 3 lines.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: De cognitione uerae uitae
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus Honorii in cognitionem vitę
msItem.incipit: Sapientia Dei quę os muti aperuit
Fratres. Gratias Deo persolvimus cuius dono per te
msItem.note: [sic: MS. Lyell 58, 12th cent., fol. 33v, also has this reading]
With an additional passage on fol. 181–181v:
msItem.incipit: Fratres [in margin] Eia hic ędere sacri ędificii
msItem.note: Inserted between cap. 37–8 of text printed in PL; it is pr. J. A. Endres, Honorius Augustodunensis, Kempten, 1906, pp. 138–40, from Munich clm. 22225.

msItem.author: Hugh of Saint-Victor
msItem.title: De archa Noe
msItem.incipit: Homo ad hoc conditus fuit ut unum tantum id est summum bonum deum amaret
msItem.explicit: (fol. 191r) in quo sunt ineffabiles delectationes in finem, id est sine fine.
msItem.note: This work, which has marginal headings: V Mansiones; quid sit cubitus; iiiiº Areas; tres voluntates; De arca gratię; De arca sapientię, etc., seems to be a shorter version of Hugh of St. Victor’s De Arca Noe (PL 176 col. 617–704). It is also found in MSS. Vienna 1165, 14th cent., in which it follows Honorius’ Cognitio Vitae, and 1561, 14th cent, from Salzburg, and was in Klosterneuburg MS. 931, listed in 1330; see Gottlieb, Mittelalt. BibLkat. Österreichs 1, 1915, p. 106 1. 18–19.

msItem.rubric: Quod autenticum sit omne quod aliquis catholicus de Deo scripserit quod canonicę scripturę contrarium non fuerit. Kathegoriarum Syllog
msItem.incipit: Deus est auctor totius boni
Lex Christum predixit. Sed Christus iam venit

msItem.rubric: Utrum totum in homine resurgat quod in corpore hominum hic fuerat
msItem.incipit: Tres opiniones sunt de resurrectione
msItem.note: This quaestio is also in MSS. St. Florian xi. 54, 14th cent., fol. 104v and Vienna 1561, fol. 25.

msItem.rubric: Utrum peccatum sit nubere vel carnes comedere
msItem.incipit: Neutrum est peccatum quia utrumque a deo est concessum

msItem.rubric: Quomodo igitur dicit idem apostolus bonum est mulierem non tangere et bonum est carnes non manducare?
msItem.incipit: Non tamen dixit peccatum est mulierem tangere
Cum idem apostolus nullum excipiat, sed omnibus generaliter dicat
msItem.note: Items d–f are pr. I. Dieterich in Introd. to Libelli Honorii Augustodunensis, Libelli de Lite 3 (1897), 34–5, from the Munich MS. already cited and MS. St. Florian xi. 54.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: De libero arbitrio
msItem.incipit: Gotscalco fide et opere sudanti in sancto proposito

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: De animae exilio et patria
msItem.incipit: Thomę gratiam apostolici nominis sortito multis donis sophyę [inserted in margin] insignito. Honorius illum in gloria

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun (?)
msItem.incipit: Legio constat ex sex milibus et sexcentis et sexaginta atque vi militibus

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Liber duodecim quaestionum
msItem.incipit: Splendore sapientię rutilo. Honorius videre fadem domini in iubilo
In hac angelica questione solvuntur XII questiones

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: De decem plagis Aegypti spiritualiter
msItem.incipit: Prima plaga erat aqua in sanguinem versa

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Quid vasa honoris et quid vasa contumeliae
msItem.rubric: Honorius. Quid vasa honoris et quid vasa contumelię
msItem.incipit: In domo magna non solum sunt vasa aurea et argentea
msItem.note: Also in MSS. St. Florian xi. 54, fol. 106; Heiligenkreuz 77, 12th–13th cent., fol. 114; Prague Univ. xiii G. 15 (2382), 15th cent., fol. 193v, and in the Klosterneuburg MS. cit., where it was ascribed to Hugo. Ed. from this MS. by M.O. Garrigues, in Studiamonastieo 20 (1978), 48–53.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: De claustrali vita
msItem.incipit: Claustralis vita est ab ipso domino instituta

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Quid sit scala ad caelum
msItem.incipit: Iacob in somnis scalam usque ad cęlos erectam vidit
msItem.note: Ed. from this MS. by M.O. Garrigues, in Studiamonastieo 20 (1978), 67–70.

msItem.author: Rupert of Deutz
msItem.title: Quaestio utrum monachis liceat praedicare
msItem.rubric: Roudpertus. Questio utrum monachis liceat predicare
msItem.incipit: Cum monachus sit mortuus seculo
msItem.note: Pr. Endres, op. cit., pp. 145–7 from Munich clm. 22225 quoting variants from our MS., then at Lambach. Also in Munich clm. 9711, 15th cent.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Quod monachis liceat praedicare
msItem.incipit: Fratres Honorio salutem. Quidam erronei nescientes de quibus loquuntur
msItem.note: Pr. Endres, op. cit., pp. 147–50 from Munich clm. 22225 with variants from our MS., then at Lambach. Also in MSS. St. Florian xi. 54; Prague Univ. xiii G. 15, fol. 199.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Quaestiones theologicae
msItem.rubric: Interrogatio. Questio de Deo utrum localis sit
msItem.incipit: Queritur utrum Deus sit in loco qui predicatur ubique esse

msItem.note: Followed by three other quaestiones, two with marginal headings

msItem.incipit: Item queritur utrum Deus ubique totus sit; Iterum queritur utrum Deus in omnibus sit. Deus est bonitas
Item queritur utrum anima in loco sit, quę corpori includi

msItem.note: A pre–1381 Heiligenkreuz inventory lists these four quaestiones as in a MS. which in general corresponds with the present MS. Heiligenkreuz 77 cit., but these quaestiones are not listed in the modern catalogue. See Gottlieb, op. cit., p. 421. 36–9. Two at least of these quaestiones are in Prague Univ. MS. xiii G. 15, following our item 14.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Quaestiones octo de angelo et homine
msItem.incipit: D. Interrogatio. Vellem mihi certa auctoritate monstrari
msItem.note: PL 172 col. 1185–92. There are lacunae on fol. 208v and 209.
There follows without a break (fol. 209v) a question headed
msItem.incipit: D. Occidi virum in vulnus meum et adolescentulum in livore meo

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Summa gloria
msItem.incipit: Pusilli gregis Christi duci verbo et exemplo ad pabula vitę previo
I. Quod sicut spirituale precellit seculare sic sacerdotium precellit regnum
Cum universitas fidelium in clerum et populum distribuatur

msItem.note: Pr. J. Dieterich in M.G.H., op. cit., pp. 63–80.
At the end of ch. 27 the scribe left half a page blank (fol. 214v) and a contemporary hand added a short passage.
msItem.incipit: Tres tamen patriarchatus sancta instituit ęcclesia.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Scala coeli maior
msItem.incipit: Frequenti meditatione animo revolvo
I. Quod religio Christiana sit navis ad patriam
Quia inter sedule disputationis documenta

msItem.note: Not identical with the text pr. in PL 172 col. 1229–40.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Sententias patrum de libero arbitrio
msItem.rubric: Ysidorus de libero arbitrio et gratia Dei
msItem.incipit: Arbitrium est voluntas liberę potestatis
msItem.note: Extracts from the fathers on free will; the extracts, with minor differences, are the same as those pr. in PL 172 col. 1226–30, following the De libero arbitrio.

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Inevitabile
msItem.incipit: Fratres in domo Dei cum consensu ambulantes
D. Queso ut me velut insipientem sufferas

msItem.note: Pr. PL 172 col. 1197–222. F. Baeumker, Das Inevitabile des H.A., in Beiträge xiii, 6, 1914, showed that this is a revised version of the Inevitabile but our MS. (fol. 232v–234v, end of De Juda to De vii Sigillis) has a fuller version of col. 1216D–1218A.
Four short pieces

msItem.incipit: Sacra scriptura quattuor modis intelligitur. Hystoria est res gesta
msItem.note: Also in Prague Univ. MS. xiii G. 15, fol. 235v.

msItem.incipit: Hierusalem triplici muro circumdata Nabuchodonosor auxilio vi regum expugnando cepit
Homo vetus et exterior et terrenus dicitur
Hebrei et Greci numerant secundum ordinem suarum litterarum

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Sacramentarium
msItem.incipit: Hunc libellum de sacramentis collegi de sanctorum scriptis
msItem.note: PL 172 col. 737–806. The arrangement in our MS. differs from the text printed in PL: many important headings are omitted, others are added. The order of chapters is: 1–111; v; iv; vi–xxxix; lxxxii–xcv; xl–lx; lxi omitted; lxii–lxxxi; xcvi–ci. The Munich MS. cit. ends fol. 128v with De resurrectione domini, which in our MS. is lxxxi–xcvi conflated.
Further short pieces:

msItem.incipit: Ieron. Quamvis Salemon peccasset, tamen egit penitentiam scribens proverbia
msItem.note: Nos. 2–3, 7–8 of the catena on the penitence of Solomon pr. R. W. Hunt in App. to R. Loewe, Alexander Neckham’s knowledge of Hebrew, Med. and Ren. Studies 4 (1958) 30–1.

msItem.incipit: Queritur de apostatis qui foris ordines suscipiunt utrum eos vere suscipiant

msItem.note: No heading
msItem.incipit: Queritur si Deus alio modo humanum genus salvare potuerit quam per mortem filii sui
Draco in hebreo proprie appellatur leviathan.
msItem.note: These four pieces appear also to be in MS. St. Florian xi. 54, fol. no–11 preceding the Sacramentarium, entitled Hieronymi quaestiones aliquot and a and b at least are also in the Munich MS. cit., fol. 129.

msItem.incipit: Vos estis sal terrę. Si igitur sal sumus, condire mentes fidelium debemus
Qui recte utitur regni potestate ita prestare se omnibus debet
Fili hominis, speculatorem dedi te domui Israel
Principes seculi nonnunquam intra ęcclesiam potestatis adeptę culmina tenent

msItem.note: On fol. 274v among other 12th–15th cent, scribbles are:

msItem.incipit: Clauditur hoc vase nostri pia victima phase
msItem.note: 12th cent. 2 lines. Cf. MS. Digby 53, fol. 21v; WIC 2870.

msItem.title: A list of Latin numbers from 30 to 1,000 with roman numerals written above (12th cent.)

msItem.incipit: Hic male defunctus non est oleo prius unctus
msItem.note: 11 lines; 12th cent.

msItem.incipit: Machmet pagnos a fide fecit prohnos
msItem.note: 15th cent.; 2 lines. The beginning of a verse against heretics found in Andreas Ratisbonensis, Chronica Pontif. et Imp. Romanorum, pr. Leidinger, Andreas von Regensburg, Sämtliche Werke, Munich, 1904, p. 144 (an. 1410). WIC 10552.

supportDesc.foliation: there is no fol. 151r; 14th cent. foliation in roman numerals written in the bottom margin of the recto
supportDesc.collation: 1⁸ (+ a leaf added after 3), 2⁸–19⁸, 20⁸ (+ 1 leaf added after 3 and another after 5), 21⁴ (4 canc.), 22⁸–26⁸, 27⁸ (8 canc.), 28⁸ (8 canc.), 29⁸–34⁸, 35⁴, 36² (1 canc.): quires 1–18 numbered in roman numerals at the end; quires 23–4 numbered II and III at the beginning; quire 29 numbered I at the end admonentur

layoutDesc.layout: 215–35 135–45 : 28–33 long lines, apart from fol. 140v–150v which are written in two cols., ruled in pencil or crayon apart from fol. 58–65v (quire viii) and fol. 165–166v, apparently ruled with a hard point

handDesc.handNote: Written in several hands in Austria (probably at Lambach) in the third quarter of the 12th cent.

There are many contemporary corrections and insertions. Some of the insertions and marginal captions by the scribes, describing the contents of the text, are enclosed in frames of red. There are also marginalia in 12th–15th-cent. hands.

decoDesc.decoNote: The MS. has a series of fine initials, mostly of the vinescroll type, drawn mainly in red but with further details in lilac or light-brown ink, sometimes with parts washed in yellow or green.

decoNote.p: Some of the initials have zoomorphic features: birds (fols. 1, 1v, 6v, 44v, 75, 192, 209v), monsters (fols. 34, 44v, 55, 97v) and a hare (fol. 108v); others have figures: the risen Christ (fol. 58v), St. John the Baptist (fols. 78v, 95: freestanding figures); heads: fol. 70r, 73r, 86r (Christ and St. Mary Magdalene), 87v (St. James), in (St. Cecilia), 113v (St. Andrew), 117 (St. Thomas), 135v (a monk). On fol. 168 is a figure of a monk, possibly intended to be Honorius himself.

The style of the initials is close to the Salzburg school of the second half of the 12th cent., and the style of drawing of the figures and faces is similar to that in the Williram codex from Lambach, now MS. Berlin theol. lat. qu. 140 (see Swarzenski, Salzburger Malerei, 1913, pp. 154–5 and Abb. 413–21) and that in the St. Augustine from Lambach (Sotheby sale, 12 Nov. 1929, lot 389, with plates) and the copy of Honorius on the Song of Songs, now Baltimore, Walters Art Gallery MS. W. 29 (ex-Lambach xciv, identified by H. Menhaxdt, Der Nachlass des H. A., in Zeitschrift für deutsches Altertum und Literatur 89 (1958–9), 60), illustrated in J. Rosenthal, Bibi. Med. Aevi MSS. H Kat. 90), 1928, Taf. viii (no. 144), and Walters Art Gallery Exhibition Catalogue, Illuminated Books of the M. Ages and Renaissance, Baltimore 1949, pl. xviil (no. 27). According to Swarzenski, the use of red and violet together in the pen drawing, with occasional use of brown ink, and of yellow wash, are characteristics of MSS. from Lambach (op. cit., p. 155). Pächt–Alexander 1, no. 80, pl. vii (fol. 58v).

binding.p: Monastic binding: original thick wooden boards, covered in 15th cent, in white leather with traces of tooling (15th cent.?), plaited head and tail bands. Remains of two clasps (15th cent.?, modern straps), traces of bosses; two labels removed from upper cover. On the early bindings of Lambach see K. Holter in Gutenberg Jahrbuch, 1954, p. 280.

history.provenance: Formerly MS. xliii in the library of the Benedictine abbey of Lambach in Austria – the shelfmark M. Memb. xliii (early 19th cent.) is on the spine, where there are also two earlier labels, now illegible. Mentioned in a list of books from the Lambach library made c. 1210, pr. by K. Holter, Zwei Bibliotheksverzeichnisse des 13 Jh., M.I.Ö.G. 64 (1956), 273; see also K. Holter Stift Lambach. Die Hss. und Inkunabeln, Österreichische Kunsttopographie xxxiv, ii (1959), 239.
Bought by Lyell in March 1942 from A. Rosenthal; see J. Rosenthal, Kat. 90 cit., no. 145 and Taf. lii (fol. 44v).
history.acquisition: Chosen as one of the hundred manuscripts bequeathed to the Bodleian by Lyell in 1948.

recordHist.source: Description adapted from A. de la Mare, Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts Bequeathed to the Bodleian Library Oxford by James P. R. Lyell (1971); with additions by Andrew Dunning. Catalogue, p. 168 Catalogue, p. 169 Catalogue, p. 170 Catalogue, p. 171 Catalogue, p. 172 Catalogue, p. 173 Catalogue, p. 174

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Revised from description by Albinia de la Mare.
